awd_titl_txt: Effects of Variation and Variability in the Acquisition of Two Dialects of Spanish
awd_abstract_narration:
Most work on language acquisition examines acquisition of language in stable and relatively homogeneous environments. In these environments typically developing children become competent speakers of the language they are exposed to quickly and efficiently. This project examines children's acquisition of grammatical properties in a much less stable but very common situation, that of language and dialect contact. Mutually intelligible dialects sometimes use the same morphological units in different ways and with different interpretations. This creates a lot of variability in the linguistic input for the learner, who then faces a linguistic situation that may provide evidence for two different and possibly incompatible grammars. Yet such children do develop their linguistic abilities and the capacity to produce and understand sentences they never heard before. Contact environments, therefore, provide a window for the researcher to examine how the learning mechanisms decide which properties of the input are "good evidence" and which are not. These environments can therefore shed light on how the learning mechanisms cope with contradictory or ambiguous input.

The principle activities will be to build two corpora of naturalistic child and adult speech of the two Spanish varieties in contact (Rioplatense Spanish and Paraguayan Spanish spoken in Buenos Aires, Argentina) and to analyze children's acquisition of grammatical properties, which exhibit variability across the two dialects. The completed corpora will be made available to other researchers worldwide (via the CHILDES database). Corpus analyses will be supplemented with experimental data and regular linguistic analysis with adult consultants. The goal is to provide both qualitative and quantitative results that can shed light on the nature of the language acquisition process and how it is affected by unstable variability.

por.por_cntn:
Children learning their first language have two main tasks: (i) to acquire the rules of a language (grammar) that will allow them to produce and comprehend sentences they never heard, and (ii) to behave linguistically like the other members of their community. In homogeneous and stable communities, although there is always some linguistic variation, this variation is probabilistically predictable for the most part. In such situations (stable variation), the child has to acquire the grammar and the frequencies of use of particular forms. There are, however, common but more complex situations, in which the child is faced with unstable variation. This is the case when where there is contact between two different systems by, for example, population displacement. In these cases, different systems may be in competition, and the child learner may be exposed to contradictory information that does not naturally lead to one particular outcome.

This project investigated the acquisition of Spanish in a situation of contact (due to population displacement) between two mutually intelligible varieties. More specifically, we examined Paraguayan migrants and their Argentinian-born children in comparison to Argentinians and their children living in Barracas, a low-income neighborhood in Buenos Aires, Argentina. We collected natural speech and experimental data from both children and adults. This data (around 400 hours of recordings) has been transcribed and formatted in such a way that it can be subjected to automatic searches using software available in CHILDES https://childes.talkbank.org/ and will soon be made available online. The natural speech data includes child-mother interactions, child-researcher interactions, mother-researcher interactions and also mother-local adult interactions, which allow for an more in-depth examination of the variation. This data has been morphologically tagged by a version of Stanza after data has been reprocessed and the tagger retrained. Although many taggers exist very few (if any) are trained in contact varieties of Spanish.

 

Using experimental data we have examined what children do when confronted with two systems of object clitic pronouns. The Argentinian variety used in Buenos Aires has a system based on gender (third person pronouns are feminine or masculine) and the Paraguayan variety uses a system based on animacy (one pronoun for animates and a zero-form for inanimates). The child has then two ways of referring to an animate masculine antecedent: the masculine form (lo) or the animate form (le). While Argentinian mothers almost categorically use the gender system, the Paraguayan mothers do not use exclusively the animacy system. Rather they have a very noisy mixture of the two systems, sometimes using all four possible forms. This is the result of a process of accommodation to the dominant variety. If Argentinian children were exposed just to their mothers they should have acquired a gender system. However, this is not what happened.  Their system shows clear use of the animacy system as well. The children of Paraguayans have, as a group a mixed system, although there is a preference for the animacy system and for a reorganization of the 4 forms into more idiosyncratic individual systems with fewer forms. In work in progress, we are using the corpus of natural speech data to be able to examine children’s individual systems in order to postulate how the grammar is being constructed for each child.

Other work we have been pursuing with the use of the corpora created involves the examination of variation in locative prepositions in children and adults, differences between adult-to-adult speech and adult to child speech and also why some properties of the Paraguayan Spanish variety are not passed on to the children exposed to the Argentinian Spanish as well. Many other individual studies are being carried out using the corpora, which fulfills a gap in the CHILDES database.
